section.title: The XDI Graph Model
section.para: The XDI Graph Model

section.title: Overview
section.para: The XDI graph is a directed acyclic graph with nodes connected by arcs. An XDI path is a connected chain of successive arcs; it forms an address designating the node at the end of the arc chain.

section.title: Nodes
section.para: There are four basic node types:

section.title: Arcs
section.para: Arcs in the XDI graph consist of an identifier with one or more context symbols or functions attached.

section.title: Literal
section.para: These are terminal and can only lead to a value node

section.title: Contextual
section.para: These express most of the XDI graph, with each arc in a path representing a specialization.

section.title: Relational
section.para: These specify equivalence or other relations between two nodes. When represented as statements, the two nodes are the subject and object of the statement, while the relation is the predicate.

section.title: Node Types
section.para: There are four (five?) types: value, variable, root, and subgraph.

section.title: Literal &
section.para: Leaf node carrying literal data value. Syntax is & (as predicate arc)

section.title: Value &
section.para: Node identifying the value of an attribute. Syntax is & (as final arc of a subject path)

section.title: Root ( )
section.para: An XDI graph starts at a root. An XDI path may start with zero, one, or multiple root expressions. Roots are enclosed in parentheses.

section.title: Outer ()
section.para: The outer root roots the whole graph and is expressed as ().

section.title: Peer (S)
section.para: Peer root Mutability depends on the XDI address inside the xref

section.title: Inner (S/P)
section.para: Inner root Mutability depends on the XDI address inside the xref

section.title: Statement (S/P/O)
section.para: Statement root Mutability depends on the XDI address inside the xref

section.title: Singleton
section.para: A single instance of a class

section.title: Entity
section.para: Entity

section.title: Attribute
section.para: Enclosing in angle brackets < > indicates an attribute as opposed to an entity.

section.title: Collection [ ]
section.para: Collection

section.title: Entity
section.para: An entity may contain subentities and attributes but not a value. Enclosing in brackets [ ] indicates a collection as opposed to a singleton.

section.title: Attribute
section.para: An attribute may only contain subattributes (and, if singular, a value)

section.title: Member # !
section.para: A node identifying an instance of an entity or attribute within a collection

section.title: XDI Graph Grammars
section.para: Grammars are given in Augmented Backus-Naur Form as defined in . Slash / is alternation, parentheses are grouping, * means zero or more of following, 1* means one or more of following, brackets [] mean zero or one of following, i.e. optional.
The XDI graph's grammar is independent of serialization. Each serialization is defined by adding a small grammar defining its delimiters, the productions in all capital letters.
XDI values are JSON values, and the JSON grammar is included for non-normative reference.

section.title: Statement Grammar
section.programlisting:
statement-list = STARTLIST statement *(STMTSEP statement) ENDLIST statement = STARTSTMT (contextual-statement / relational-statement / literal-statement) ENDSTMT contextual-statement = direct-contextual / inverse-contextual direct-contextual = absolute / root-relative / context-relative / collection-relative inverse-contextual = absolute-inverse / root-inverse / context-inverse / collection-inverse absolute = outer-root SUBPRED outer-root PREDOBJ xdi-paths root-relative = relative-root SUBPRED outer-root PREDOBJ xdi-paths context-relative = xdi-path SUBPRED outer-root PREDOBJ relative-contexts collection-relative =collection-context SUBPRED outer-root PREDOBJ member-contexts absolute-inverse = xdi-path SUBPRED "$is" outer-root PREDOBJ outer-root root-inverse = xdi-path SUBPRED "$is" outer-root PREDOBJ relative-root context-inverse = relative-context SUBPRED "$is" outer-root PREDOBJ xdi-paths collection-inverse = member-context SUBPRED "$is" outer-root PREDOBJ collection-contexts
relational-statement = inverse-relational / direct-relational direct-relational = xdi-path SUBPRED xdi-path PREDOBJ ( xdi-path / outer-root / xdi-paths) inverse-relational = xdi-path SUBPRED "$is" xdi-path PREDOBJ ( xdi-path / outer-root / xdi-paths)
literal-statement = literal-context "&" SUBPRED "&" PREDOBJ json-value

section.title: Path Grammar
section.para: An XDI path can contain roots, then entities, then attributes, then value, in that order. Each of those elements is optional, except that a value must be preceded by an attribute singleton or attribute member.
section.programlisting: xdi-path = *root-node *entity-node *attribute-node [ attribute-value ] entity-node = ( entity-singleton / ( entity-collection *entity-member ) ) attribute-node = ( attribute-singleton / ( attribute-collection *attribute-member ) ) attribute-value = ( attribute-singleton / ( attribute-collection 1*attribute-member ) ) value
section.para: The following section is probably obsolete. Please confirm.
section.programlisting: xdi-path = outer-root / ( 1*relative-root [ relative-context ] ) / relative-context ; ND equivalent to *relative-root *subpath minus the empty case relative-context = 1*subpath collection-context = [ 1*relative-root ] collection-path ; ND *relative-root *subpath collection collection-path = ( subpath collection-path ) / collection member-context = 1*member [ relative-context ] ; ND 1*member *subpath literal-context = [ 1*relative-root ] literal-path literal-path = ( subpath literal-path ) / attribute-singleton / attribute-path ; ND *subpath ( attribute-singleton / attribute-path ) attribute-path = attribute-collection 1*member subpath = singleton / ( collection [ 1*member ] ) / definition / variable

section.title: Unfactored Root Grammar
section.para: This alternative does not factor the parentheses out of the root definition.
section.programlisting: root-node = outer-root / relative-root outer-root = "()" relative-root = peer-root / inner-root / statement-root peer-root = xref inner-root = "(" xdi-path SUBPRED xdi-path ")" statement-root = "(" statement ")" xref = "(" ( xdi-path / presumed-iri / xdi-identifier ) ")"

section.title: Factored Root Grammar
section.para: This alternative factors the parentheses out of the root definition.
section.programlisting: root-node = outer-root / relative-root outer-root = "(" ")" relative-root = "(" ( peer-root / inner-root / statement-root ) ")" peer-root = xref inner-root = xdi-path SUBPRED xdi-path statement-root = statement xref = ( xdi-path / presumed-iri / xdi-identifier )
section.para: Note that since a statement is a subject / predicate / object triple, a root may contain a 3-tuple (statement), 2-tuple (inner root), or 1-tuple (path) of XDI paths; or an XDI identifier or an IRI.

section.title: Arc Grammar
section.para: These describe an individual directed edge in the XDI graph.

general-collection = ordered-collection / unordered-collection / singleton-collection singleton-collection = "[*]" SYMSEP

section.title: Display Format Statement Serialization Grammar
section.para: XDI Display Format is a compact human-readable representation of XDI paths and statements using a minimum of delimiters, but is not in a standard data interchange format such as JSON. Each statement is on a separate line, and the subject/predicate/object of a triple are separated by the slash /.
Multiline XDI Display Format allows a subject/predicate pair to by followed by multiple objects, indicated by indentation.

section.title: JSON Grammar
section.para: Based on syntax diagrams (no actual grammar rules found there) restricted for canonical form (add reference) canonicality restrictions: no + signs, no leading zeros, no trailing zeros on fraction
Get ABNF from 4427 and/or ECMA
We use JSON values, i.e. a value may be a single string, number, true, false, or null, not necessarily a JSON array or object, as is required by "JSON text" in the JSON MIME type specification.
XDI processors SHOULD accept non-canonical JSON values as input.
XDI processors MAY output partly, fully, or not at all canonicalized versions of JSON values that clients have input, for example by removing spaces.
XDI processors SHOULD fully canonicalize JSON values that are results and not user input.
Canonical form includes:
No unnecessary whitespace
Nonzero numbers have no leading zeros or preceding + sign in either fraction or exponent
An exponent is preceded by uppercase E
Hex in \u character escapes should be lowercase
section.programlisting: json-value = json-object / json-array / json-string / json-number / "true" / "false" / "null" json-object = "{" [ json-string ":" json-value *( "," json-string ":" json-value ) ] "}" json-array = "[" [ json-value *( "," json-value ) ] "]" json-string = QUOTE *( " " / "!" / %x23-5B / %x5D-EFFFD / json-char-escape ) QUOTE json-char-escape = "\" ("\" / "/" / "b" / "f" / "n" / "r" / "t" / QUOTE / ( "u" 4HEX ) ) json-number = ( "0" / [ "-" ] noleading ) [ "." notrailing ] [ "E" [ "-" ] noleading ] noleading = %x31-39 *DIGIT notrailing = *DIGIT %x31-39

section.title: Identifier Grammar
section.para: A simple IRI grammar is a lightweight initial parsing alternative to the full IRI grammar in . An XDI processor MAY check an IRI for full compliance with all details of IRI syntax, but this may not be necessary unless the XDI processor is about to use or dereference the IRI.
section.programlisting:
presumed-iri = %x61-7A *( %x61-7A / DIGIT ) ":" *iri-body ; Quick check for something that looks like an IRI without checking body details iri-body = ( "(" iri-body ")" ) / *iri-char ; paired "(" and ")" are allowed in body iri-char = xdi-identifier-char / context-symbol / other-iri-delim context-symbol = "!" / "*" / "=" / "@" / "+" / "$" other-iri-delim = "/" / "?" / "#" / "[" / "]" / "'" / ","
xdi-identifier = *xdi-identifier-char ; Note: Includes any JSON numbers xdi-identifier-char = %x41-5A / %x61-7A / DIGIT / "-" / "." / "_" / %x80-EFFFD ; ISSUE - is there a way to leave high end open?
HEX = DIGIT / %x61-66 DIGIT = %x30-39 NZDIG = %x31-39 QUOTE = %x22 ENDLINE = %x0D / %x0A / ( %x0D %x0A )
section.para: Hex digits in ipv6, uuid are lowercase; only the exponent prefix E in JSON numbers is uppercase.
